Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Understanding the Micromechanisms of Growth and Remodeling of Collagenous Tissues

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award is to investigate the fundamental microscale mechanisms of growth and remodeling of collagenous tissues. Collagen structures impart stiffness, strength, and toughness to a variety of soft tissues including blood vessels, skin, and the cornea. Mechanical stimuli can alter the production and organization of collagen structures, leading to growth and remodeling, through a variety of active cellular mechanisms and passive microscale mechanisms. The research will focus on a model biological tissue, the sclera of experimental glaucoma mouse eyes subjected to chronic intraocular pressure (IOP) elevation. We hypothesize that growth and remodeling of the sclera in response to pathological loading is strongly influenced by 3 microscale mechanisms: (1) strain-induced collagen degradation and accumulation, (2) collagen crimp remodeling, and (3) myofibroblast (cellular) matrix contraction. The proposed work will develop new experimental methods, including an inflation experiment using confocal microscopy and a digital volume correlation (DVC), to measure changes in mechanical properties, collagen structure, and cellular features caused by chronic IOP elevation; and constitutive models for growth and remodeling based on the 3 hypothesized mechanisms.

If successful, these studies will add significantly to understanding how mechanical loading influences growth and remodeling of collagen tissues. This will have direct translation to the study and treatment of a range of diseases, such as tendon injuries, cardiac fibrosis, and glaucoma. The basic research of the proposal is important to public health, because glaucoma is the second leading cause of blindness in the world. The educational program focuses on course development on biomechanics and on creating opportunities for high school, undergraduate, and graduate students to participate in biomechanics research. The research program is multidisciplinary and collaborative in nature. All student investigators will interact closely with ophthalmologist and biophysicist collaborators to learn a breadth of knowledge not found in traditional engineering education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research goals of this project were to investigate using a combined experimental and modeling approach the mechanisms of growth and remodeling of soft connective tissues. Soft connective tissues, like those of the heart, eye wall, tendons, and skin, are composed primarily of collagen molecules organized in fibers, which are further organized in a soft matrix of other proteins and water into tissue structures.  Growth describes changing the mass of the tissue, which can cause changes in volume and density, while remodeling describes changing the microstructure and mechanical properties.  We developed innovative experimental tools using multiphoton microscopy and digital image correlation analysis of the microscopy images to measure changes in the collagen structure of the sclera and lamina cribrosa, the soft connective tissues of the eye, with age and glaucoma and the effects of the microstructural changes on the mechanical behavior of the tissues. We also developed fundamental models to test hypotheses of how mechanical loading affects collagen degradation by enzymes and collagen deposition onto collagen fibers, and how the concurrent actions of collagen deposition and degradation can lead to growth and remodeling of collagen tissues.  Our most significant findings are as follows. The stiffness of the human sclera and lamina cribrosa increase significantly with age and glaucoma. Specifically, we found the stiffness of the soft matrix increased but no significant increase in the stiffness of the collagen fiber.  The increase in the stiffness of the matrix may be caused by loss of glycosaminoglycans in the matrix with age, which may cause additional crosslinking between collagen fibrils, and increased interfibrillar crosslinking from glycation. The increase in stiffness is more variable with glaucoma and the degree of stiffening varies with the severity of optic nerve damage in glaucoma. These fundamental findings may lead to advanced screening methods for glaucoma that involves mechanical measurements of the stiffness of the sclera and lamina cribrosa.  

            The modeling studies showed the key mechanisms of mechanical inhibition of collagen degradation and mechanics stimulation of collagen deposition can explain many important phenomena of growth and remodeling.  Mechanical inhibition of collagen degradation leads to remodeling of the orientation of the collagen structure along the direction of principal stress and degree of alignment according to the stress state. This mechanism plays an important role in how tissues can adapt to the physiological loading conditions. Moreover, the concurrent action of mechanics stimulated collagen deposition and mechanics inhibition of degradation can lead to stress homeostasis, where the tissue structure adapts to return the native stress state to a physiological target. These findings increase fundamental knowledge of how mechanical loading can be applied to direct the growth and remodeling of engineered tissues and how disease can alter the mechanical behavior of tissues.  

            This project provided research opportunities for 3 PhD students (2 women) and an undergraduate woman student. The students and PI have mentored 4 women high school students in semester long or summer long research projects on biomechanics of the eye.  We have also participated as mentors for an afterschool program STEM Achievement in Baltimore Elementary School (SABES), that enhances science education in Baltimore City elementary schools in economically disadvantaged neighborhoods.
